newsitem.title: BOTSWANA: Botswana businesses list top privatisation targets.
newsitem.headline: Botswana businesses list top privatisation targets.

text.p: Botswana's private sector has listed parastatals and government departments it considers ripe for privatisation in a report welcomed by the government at the weekend.

"Our analysis showed there is substantial potential for privatisation in Botswana," Modiri Mbaakanyi, director of the Botswana Confederation of Commerce, Industry and Manpower, told reporters late on Friday.

The report, compiled by Coopers and Lybrand accountants for Mbaakanyi, named the Botswana Meat Commission (BMC), Botswana Telecommunications Corp (BTC) and loss-making Air Botswana as top candidates for public share issues.
"Opportunities for quick successes should be identified in order to demonstrate that the programme can obtain results," said the report.
"At least one public issue should be promoted to attract public attention to the programme."
Finance Minister Festus Mogae welcomed the report.
"The issue of privatisation has been exercising our minds for some time," he told Mbaakanyi.
BTC had a trading profit in 1995/96 of 18.5 million pula ($5.2 million). It has 60,000 subscribers, with demand growing 20 percent a year.
The report suggests privatisation as a joint venture competing in a freer telecommunications environment with other newly licensed operators.
Two cellular network licences are due to be granted soon. BTC will bid for one with a joint venture partner.
BMC had a 40.8 million pula operating profit in 1995/96. It has capital and reserves of 147 million pula.
Botswana Airways has 270 staff, more than it has seats on its three aircraft. It flies 100,000 passengers a year.
Debt of 75 million pula was written off in 1994 after capital restructuring, but the airline lost 2.1 million pula in 1994/95. A similar loss is projected for 1995/96.
The report listed seven parastatals and departments for immediate privatisation and five others, plus some local councils, as candidates to hand over some operations to the private sector.
Immediate privatisation was also suggested for the debt-ridden Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC).
Botswana Savings Bank was named as a candidate to go private but it was felt unlikely there would be interest.
Major contracting out of services was recommended for Gaborone City Council, Botswana Railways, the Department of Supply and the Government Printer.
The Botswana Power Corporation was not seen as a candidate for a major privatisation project.
More than 20 other parastatals, departments and councils not examined in detail were listed as possibly suitable for complete or partial takeover.
The Bank of Botswana headed this list.
The report said a start should be made by running the public sector along more commercial lines.

"An arms-length relationship should be established between government and parastatals which would give the parastatals greater freedom in taking pricing, operational and investment decisions," the report said.
"There will be be significant revenue for the government," it added. "This could all amount to hundreds of millions of pula annually."
